topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Ami Vora’s background (Facebook, Instagram ads, WhatsApp, Faire) and previews key topics like disagreement, metaphors, and goals. Ami shares her intention to be authentic and normalize “messy” success.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Sidebar (peer leadership groups) and Anvil (document workflow SDK).

topics.title: Choosing roles by “feel” and trust
topics.summary: Ami explains her approach to career decisions: do the rational “spreadsheet,” then focus on the emotional signal of whether the job feels like home. She emphasizes trust, risk-taking, and feeling lucky to be there as predictors of doing great work.

topics.title: Disagreeing with curiosity, not ego
topics.summary: Lenny reads Boz’s quote about Ami’s ability to respond to disagreement with genuine curiosity (“Fascinating, tell me more”). Ami describes learning to sublimate ego, assume others have missing context, and use pauses plus feedback loops to turn conflict into learning.

topics.title: Dinosaur brain: how to run product reviews
topics.summary: Ami shares why execs (including herself) can only hold a few facts at once and need teams to bring clear recommendations. She reframes reviews as principle-calibration (not decision-by-decision), advocates minimal writing, short/pointed forums, and thoughtful attendee selection.

topics.title: Metaphors to align teams: hill climb
topics.summary: Ami explains the “hill climb” metaphor: leaving a local optimum requires descending into a valley to reach a higher global optimum, which helps set expectations for temporary pain. They discuss why narrative and imagery scale decision-making across teams.

topics.title: Building metaphors and leader “emulators”
topics.summary: Ami describes learning metaphor-building from a manager by starting with the user feeling (e.g., “Dolores Park on a sunny Saturday”). She also shares her practice of mentally “emulating” leaders (storytelling, principles, metrics) to unlock different problem-solving lenses.

topics.title: WhatsApp product narrative: face-to-face communication
topics.summary: Ami gives a concrete example of narrative guiding product decisions at WhatsApp: designing for the universality and intimacy of face-to-face communication across device and market constraints. She ties small UX details (typing indicators, read receipts, lightweight calls) to the feeling of presence.

topics.title: Execution beats strategy (and why)
topics.summary: Ami argues that customers only experience shipped product, so perfect strategy with poor execution teaches you nothing, while strong execution enables rapid learning and strategy iteration. She discusses why strategy is glamorous but execution is the real driver of outcomes.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for UserTesting (fast customer feedback to reduce risk and rework).

topics.title: Balancing strategy vs execution by seniority
topics.summary: Ami suggests spending a minority of time on strategy and most on validating with customers and building an execution machine; even senior leaders execute by unblocking systems and staying close to customer reality. She emphasizes strategy must change team behavior to improve customer outcomes.
